<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	General and administrative expenses amounted to &#128;12.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and
	increased by &#128;1.5&nbsp;million, or 12%, to &#128;13.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. This increase was principally due to personnel costs, which increased by &#128;0.9&nbsp;million, or 13%, from &#128;7.2&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;8.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, resulting from various effects, such as increased costs of share-based payments plans (warrant plans) and change in classification between
	R&amp;D and general and administrative expenditure for some management functions. In addition, other operating expenses increased by &#128;0.6&nbsp;million, or 11%, from &#128;5.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;5.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, mainly due to higher professional fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	General and administrative expenses increased
	by &#128;5.2&nbsp;million, or 38%, to &#128;19.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. This increase was principally due to personnel costs and directors fees, which increased by &#128;4.6&nbsp;million, or 58%, from
	&#128;8.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 to &#128;12.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, resulting from various effects, such as increased costs of share-based payments plans (warrant plans) and
	increased provision for short- and long-term management bonus, mainly as a result of the evolution of our share price change relative to the Next Biotech Index on Euronext. In addition, other operating expenses increased by &#128;0.6&nbsp;million,
	or 10%, from &#128;5.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 to &#128;6.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, mainly due to higher professional fees.
</P>

	F-24
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage197"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Sales and marketing expenses decreased by &#128;0.5&nbsp;million, or 32%, from &#128;1.5&nbsp;million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;1.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Sales and marketing expenses increased by
	&#128;0.2&nbsp;million, or 19%, to &#128;1.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>

	The restructuring and integration costs amounted to &#128;0.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and to
	&#128;0.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and were entirely related to workforce reductions within certain of the R&amp;D operations.

	The other personnel costs mainly relate to costs for warrants granted of &#128;2.9&nbsp;million (2014: &#128;2.2 million;
	2013: &#128;1.8 million). For the costs of warrants granted, see

	note 30

	.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	7. Fair value re-measurement of share subscription agreement
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;16, 2015, Gilead Sciences, Inc. and Galapagos NV entered into a global collaboration for the development
	and commercialization of filgotinib, in the framework of which Gilead committed to an upfront payment of $725 million consisting of a license fee of $300 million and a $425 million equity investment in Galapagos NV by subscribing to new shares at a
	price of &#128;58&nbsp;per share, including issuance premium. This agreement was effectively completed and entered into force January&nbsp;19, 2016 and full payment was received.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the agreement, we recognized a deferred income and an offsetting short-term financial asset (derivative) of
	&#128;39&nbsp;million upon signing of the share subscription agreement with Gilead as required under IAS 39. This financial asset initially reflects the share premium that Gilead committed to pay above the closing stock price of Galapagos on the day
	of entering into the subscription agreement. Under IAS 39 the fair value of the financial asset is re-measured at year-end and again upon entering into force of the subscription agreement on January&nbsp;19, 2016, when the financial asset expired.
	Variations in fair value of the financial asset are recorded in the income statement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-25
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage198"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The decrease in the fair value of the financial asset resulting from the increase in the
	Galapagos share price between signing of the subscription agreement and December&nbsp;31, 2015 resulted in a negative, non-cash fair value charge of &#128;30.6&nbsp;million in the financial results. The subsequent increase in the fair value of the
	financial asset resulting from the decrease in the Galapagos share price between January&nbsp;1, 2016 and January&nbsp;19, 2016 will result in a positive non-cash gain of &#128;57.5&nbsp;million in the financial result of the first quarter of 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	8. Other financial income / expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table summarizes other finance income and expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other finance income increased slightly by &#128;0.1&nbsp;million, or 5%, from &#128;2.2&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;2.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other finance income decreased slightly by
	&#128;0.3&nbsp;million, or 13%, to &#128;2.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The decrease in the effect of discounting long-term R&amp;D incentives receivables (-&#128;0.8 million) was partly compensated by an increase in
	currency exchange gains (+ &#128;0.4 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other finance expense decreased by &#128;0.5&nbsp;million, or 38% from &#128;1.4&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;0.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily reflecting lower exchange rate losses arising from U.S. dollars. Interest expenses are related to interests paid on financial lease.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other finance expense increased by &#128;0.6&nbsp;million, or 77% to &#128;1.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. Net exchange loss
	amounts to &#128; 0.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to &#128;0.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Interest expenses are related to interests paid on financial lease.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-26
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Current tax representing &#128;0.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was related to taxes for
	subsidiaries operating on cost plus basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Current tax recorded in 2014 for an amount of &#128;2.4&nbsp;million related to a tax provision for
	subsidiaries operating under cost plus transfer pricing arrangements, triggered by a tax audit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Deferred tax income of &#128;1.4&nbsp;million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and &#128;0.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 both related to subsidiaries working on a cost plus basis. Deferred tax charges representing &#128;0.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013 related to the reversal of a deferred tax asset on tax losses carried forward in Croatia. Due to a revised business strategy of the subsidiary in 2013 (transition towards service company), the company would no longer be in a
	taxable position or even be profitable in the foreseeable future, which explained the reversal of the deferred tax asset.
</P>

<B>
	Total tax liabilities

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The tax liabilities amounting to &#128;2.6&nbsp;million on December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 are primarily related to the
	recognition of tax liabilities for one of the subsidiaries operating on a cost plus basis for &#128;2.1&nbsp;million as a consequence of a tax audit. In addition, taxes on gain on the sale of the service division in 2014 are included in the tax
	liabilities for &#128;0.4 million. The income tax expense in connection with the sale of the service division was only &#128;0.4&nbsp;million, since the gain is considered as a capital gain under Belgian tax law, which is subject to a tax rate of
	less than 1%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-27
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage200"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Corporation tax is calculated at 34% (2014 and 2013: 34%)-which is the tax rate applied in Belgium-of the
	estimated assessable profit for the year. The applied tax rate for other territorial jurisdictions is the tax rate that is applicable in these respective territorial jurisdictions on the estimated taxable result of the accounting year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The main difference between the theoretical tax and the effective tax for the year 2015 is primarily explained by the
	unrecognized deferred tax assets on tax losses carried forward for which we conservatively assess that it is not likely that these will be realized in the foreseeable future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The main difference between the theoretical tax and the effective tax for the year 2014 is primarily explained by low capital gain tax (less than 1%) under
	Belgian tax law, on the gain on sale of the service division (see line non-taxable revenues and effect of consolidation entries), and by the unrecognized deferred tax assets on tax losses carried forward for which we conservatively assess that it is
	not likely that these will be realized in the foreseeable future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Non-taxable revenues for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014 and 2015 related
	to non-taxable subsidies and tax credits.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-28
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage201"></A>

	The service division was sold on April&nbsp;1, 2014. The above table illustrates the results of the discontinued operations
	included in the consolidated results of operations for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, results only relate to the period from January&nbsp;1, 2014 through the disposal on
	April&nbsp;1, 2014.
</P>

	Net income amounting to &#128;70.5&nbsp;million in 2014 was mainly driven by the &#128;67.5&nbsp;million gain on disposal of the
	service division.

<A NAME="eolPage202"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	11. Result per share
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Basic result per share and diluted result per share are calculated by dividing the net result attributable to shareholders by the weighted
	average number of ordinary shares issued during the year:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Income / loss per share
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As our continuing operations report a net loss, the outstanding warrants (specified in
<I>
	note 30
</I>
	) have an anti-dilutive
	effect rather than a dilutive effect. Consequently, basic and diluted loss per share are the same.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	12. Goodwill
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	The decrease of the goodwill to &#128;0 in 2014 was exclusively due to the sale of the service division to Charles River. We
	do not have goodwill related to our continuing operations in our balance sheet.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The intangible assets decreased by &#128;5.8&nbsp;million from &#128;7.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2013, to
	&#128;2.0&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. This decrease was mainly due to the sale of the service division on April&nbsp;1, 2014 by &#128;5.5&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-31
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage204"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The intangible assets decreased by &#128;0.5&nbsp;million from &#128;2&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014, to
	&#128;1.5&nbsp;million at December 31, 2015. The amortization of &#128;1.0&nbsp;million was partly compensated by new additions for &#128;0.5 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	14. Property, plant and equipment
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="5%">
</TD>

</TD>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="5%">

</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-32
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage205"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The property, plant and equipment decreased from &#128;19.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;10.1&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. This decrease is mainly the result of the sale of the service division, both on lines &#145;Sales and disposals&#146; (assets carved out) and &#145;Sale of the Service division&#146;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The property, plant and equipment increased from &#128;10.1&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014 to &#128;13.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. This
	increase is mainly the result of new additions of &#128;6.1&nbsp;million, partly compensated by a depreciation charge of &#128;2.4 million. The sales and disposals in 2015 relate to the move to new premises in France and The Netherlands.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There are no pledged items of property, plant and equipment. There are also no restrictions in use on any items of property, plant and equipment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

	15. Research and Development incentives receivables
</B>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total R&amp;D incentives receivables increased by &#128;1.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to
	December&nbsp;31, 2013. This increase is explained by a new R&amp;D incentives reported in 2014 for &#128;11.9&nbsp;million (&#128;7.6 million related to French R&amp;D incentives and &#128;4.3&nbsp;million related to Belgian R&amp;D incentives)
	less the payment received related to French R&amp;D incentives amounting to &#128;8.6 million. The remaining variance of &#128;1.9&nbsp;million was explained by the phasing out of the consolidation scope of the service division which contributed to
	the total current R&amp;D receivables at the end of 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total R&amp;D incentives receivables increased by &#128;7.2&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to December&nbsp;31, 2014. This increase is explained by new R&amp;D incentives reported in 2015 for &#128;14.0&nbsp;million (&#128;8.7 million related to French R&amp;D incentives and &#128;5.3&nbsp;million related
	to Belgian R&amp;D incentives) less the payment received related to French R&amp;D incentives amounting to &#128;6.7 million. The R&amp;D incentives receivables relate to future refunds resulting from R&amp;D incentives on research expenses in
	France and Belgium. Non-current R&amp;D incentives receivables are discounted over the period until maturity date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-33
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Restricted cash amounted to &#128;10.7&nbsp;million on December&nbsp;31, 2014, and decreased to &#128;7.9&nbsp;million on
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. This decrease is related to (a)&nbsp;the release of the &#128;3&nbsp;million bank guarantee issued in 2013 for the rental of the new premises in France which expired on June&nbsp;30, 2015 following the move to the new
	offices, (b)&nbsp;the payment of a claim to Charles River by decrease of the escrow account, and (c)&nbsp;a &#128;0.7&nbsp;million bank guarantee issued in September 2015 for the rental of new premises in The Netherlands (to replace the current
	premises) which will expire on October&nbsp;1, 2025. Restricted cash on December&nbsp;31, 2015 is related to &#128;0.3&nbsp;million and &#128;0.7&nbsp;million bank guarantees on real estate lease obligations in Belgium and in The Netherlands
	respectively, and to &#128;6.9&nbsp;million escrow account containing part of the proceeds from the sale of the service division in 2014 for which the release will be possible after final agreement between the parties on the exposure regarding one
	outstanding claim. An amount of &#128;0.3&nbsp;million has been accrued in 2015 based on a preliminary estimate of the exposure.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-34
</P>

	The movements in 2014 presented in the table above resulted primarily from the sale of the service division.

	We consider that the carrying amount of trade and other receivables approximates their fair value. The other current assets mainly include accrued income from
	subsidy projects and deferred charges.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We reported a cash position of &#128;187.7&nbsp;million at the end of December 2014 compared to &#128;138.2&nbsp;million at
	year-end 2013. The operating activities reported use of &#128;75.6&nbsp;million of cash in 2014 while the investing activities brought &#128;120.6&nbsp;million of cash in-flow mainly due the proceeds from the sale of the service division
	(&#128;130.8 million) and &#128;4.2&nbsp;million from the financing activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We reported a cash position of &#128;340.3&nbsp;million at the end of
	December 2015. The operating and investing activities reported use of respectively &#128;114.6&nbsp;million and &#128;4.3&nbsp;million of cash in 2015 while the financing activities brought &#128;271.4&nbsp;million of cash in-flow mainly due to the
	proceeds of a recent global offering and concurrent listing on NASDAQ (&#128;259.4 million) and due to warrant exercises (&#128;12 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash and
	cash equivalents comprise cash in hand and short-term bank deposits or short-term highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to cash and are subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. Our cash management strategy monitors and
	optimizes our liquidity position. Our cash management strategy may allow short-term deposits with an original maturity exceeding 3 months while monitoring all liquidity aspects. Cash and cash equivalents comprise &#128;100&nbsp;million of term
	deposits with an original maturity longer than 3 months. All cash and cash equivalent is available upon maximum one month notice period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-35
</P>

	Costs of capital increases are netted against the proceeds of capital increases, in accordance with IAS 32 Financial
	instruments: disclosure and presentation.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-36
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage209"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;1, 2013, the share capital of Galapagos NV amounted to &#128;144,815.6&nbsp;thousand, represented
	by 26,770,747 shares. All shares were issued, fully paid up and of the same class.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;5, 2013, warrants were exercised at various exercise
	prices (with an average exercise price of &#128;5.98&nbsp;per warrant). The exercise resulted in a share capital increase of &#128;1,069&nbsp;thousand (plus &#128;113&nbsp;thousand in issuance premium) and the issuance of 197,581 new shares. The
	closing price of the Galapagos share at this date was &#128;18.38.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;29, 2013, within the framework of the authorized capital and with
	cancellation of the preferential subscription rights, the Board of Directors of Galapagos NV decided to increase the share capital by &#128;14,589.9&nbsp;thousand (plus &#128;39,346.8&nbsp;thousand in issuance premium) by means of a private
	placement with institutional investors, resulting in the issuance of 2,696,831 new shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2013, warrants were exercised at various
	exercise prices (with an average exercise price of &#128;6.48&nbsp;per warrant). The exercise resulted in a share capital increase of &#128;487.7&nbsp;thousand (plus &#128;96.5&nbsp;thousand in issuance premium) and the issuance of 90,143 new
	shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share on July&nbsp;1, 2013, was &#128;15.67.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;21, 2013, warrants were exercised at various
	exercise prices (with an average exercise price of &#128;6.80&nbsp;per warrant) resulting in a share capital increase of &#128;193.2&nbsp;thousand (plus &#128;49.6&nbsp;thousand in issuance premium) and the issuance of 35,719 new shares. The closing
	price of the Galapagos share at this date was &#128;15.25.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;6, 2013, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an average
	exercise price of &#128;6.35&nbsp;per warrant). The exercise resulted in a share capital increase of &#128;16.3&nbsp;thousand (plus &#128;2.9&nbsp;thousand in issuance premium) and the issuance of 3,025 new shares. The closing price of the Galapagos
	share on December&nbsp;6, 2013, was &#128;14.14.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;1, 2014, Galapagos NV&#146;s share capital amounted to &#128;161,171.6&nbsp;thousand,
	represented by 29,794,046 shares. All shares were issued, fully paid up and of the same class.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;10, 2014, warrants were exercised at various
	exercise prices (with an average exercise price of &#128;7.81&nbsp;per warrant) resulting in a share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;2,381.2&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 304,791 new ordinary shares. The closing price of
	the Galapagos share at this date was &#128;16.80.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;4, 2014, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an average exercise
	price of &#128;10.26&nbsp;per warrant), resulting in a share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;1,862.3&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 181,507 new ordinary shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share on July&nbsp;4, 2014,
	was &#128;15.13.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;25, 2014, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an average exercise price of &#128;10.60&nbsp;per
	warrant), resulting in a share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;130.0&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 12,260 new ordinary shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share at this date was &#128;12.19.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;9, 2014, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an average exercise price of &#128;8.61&nbsp;per warrant), resulting in a
	share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;56.2&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 6,525 new ordinary shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share on December&nbsp;9, 2014, was &#128;14.77.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;31, 2014, Galapagos NV&#146;s share capital amounted to &#128;163,904.1&nbsp;thousand, represented by 30,299,129 shares. All shares were
	issued, fully paid up and of the same class.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;26, 2015, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an average exercise price
	of &#128;10.18&nbsp;per warrant), resulting in a share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;5,819&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 571,548 new ordinary shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share at this date was &#128;21.26.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-37
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage210"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;19, 2015, Galapagos completed a global offering of 7,532,499 ordinary shares consisting of a
	concurrent public offering in the United States and private placement in Europe and countries other than the United States and Canada. Galapagos offered 5,746,000 ordinary shares through a public offering in the United States in the form of American
	Depositary Shares, or ADSs, at a price of $42.05 per ADS, before underwriting discounts. The ADSs are evidenced by American Depositary Receipts, or ADRs, and each ADS represents the right to receive one ordinary share. The ADSs are listed on the
	NASDAQ Global Select Market under the symbol &#147;GLPG.&#148; Galapagos offered 1,786,499 ordinary shares through a private placement in Europe and countries other than the United States and Canada at a price of &#128;37.00&nbsp;per share, before
	underwriting discounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Galapagos received &#128;278.7&nbsp;million of gross proceeds from the global offering, decreased by &#128;19.4&nbsp;million of
	underwriter discounts and commission, and offering expenses, of which &#128;19.3&nbsp;million has been paid at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and &#128;0.1&nbsp;million remains to be settled in cash. The total net cash proceeds from the global offering
	after remaining settlements will amount to &#128;259.3 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;19, 2015, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an
	average exercise price of &#128;8.94&nbsp;per warrant), resulting in a share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;4,395&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 491,406 new ordinary shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share on
	June&nbsp;19, 2015, was &#128;46.73.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;25, 2015, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an average exercise price of
	&#128;10.13&nbsp;per warrant), resulting in a share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;1,198&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 118,260 new ordinary shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share at this date was &#128;44.75.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;4, 2015, warrants were exercised at various exercise prices (with an average exercise price of &#128;9.30&nbsp;per warrant), resulting
	in a share capital increase (including issuance premium) of &#128;590.8&nbsp;thousand and the issuance of 63,500 new ordinary shares. The closing price of the Galapagos share on December&nbsp;4, 2015, was &#128;44.78.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;31, 2015, Galapagos NV&#146;s share capital amounted to &#128;211,388.9&nbsp;thousand, represented by 39,076,342 shares. All shares were
	issued, fully paid up and of the same class.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	All of the share issuances listed above were for cash consideration.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-38
</P>

	Par value of shares (&#128;)

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Board of Directors is authorized for a period of five years starting from the date of the Shareholders&#146; Meeting that
	granted the renewed authorization, being May&nbsp;23, 2011, to increase the share capital of Galapagos NV within the framework of the authorized capital through contributions in kind or in cash, with limitation or cancellation of the
	shareholders&#146; preferential subscription rights. Said authorization can be renewed. The Board of Directors is currently not authorized to increase the share capital after notification by the FSMA (Financial Services and Markets Authority) of a
	public takeover bid on Galapagos NV&#146;s shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-39
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage212"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The authorized capital as approved by the Extraordinary General Shareholders&#146; Meeting of May&nbsp;23, 2011
	amounted to &#128;142,590.8 thousand. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, &#128;72,180&nbsp;thousand of the authorized capital was used, so that an amount of &#128;70,410.7&nbsp;thousand still remained available.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	20. Other reserves
</B>
</P>

	recognized through other comprehensive income

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The other reserves amounted to a negative of &#128;18&nbsp;thousand (2014: &#128;220 thousand; 2013; positive of &#128;47
	thousand) and related to the re-measurement of defined benefit obligations booked through OCI in line with IAS19R.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<U>
	D
<SMALL>
	ERIVATIVE
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	FINANCIAL
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	INSTRUMENTS
</SMALL>
	:
<SMALL>
	CURRENCY
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	DERIVATIVES
</SMALL>
</U>
<SMALL>
</SMALL>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We do not actively use currency derivatives to hedge planned future cash flows. On the balance sheet
	date, total notional amount of outstanding forward foreign exchange contracts that we have committed are nil (2014 and 2013: nil).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;31,
	2015 the fair value of the currency derivatives is nil (2014 and 2013: nil).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We do not designate our foreign currency denominated debt as a hedge
	instrument for the purpose of hedging the translation of our foreign operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	See
<I>
	note 35
</I>
	for further information on how financial risks are
	managed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Translation differences decreased to a negative of &#128;1.2&nbsp;million at the end of December 2014 mainly due to the sale
	of the service division which reported positive translation differences of &#128;2.0&nbsp;million at the end of December 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Translation differences
	increased from a negative &#128;1.2&nbsp;million at the end of December 2014 to a negative of &#128;0.5&nbsp;million at the end of December 2015 mainly due to the increase of the GBP and USD exchange rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-40
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage213"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The notional interest deduction for an amount of &#128;2.6&nbsp;million (2014 and 2013: &#128;2.6 million) and the investment
	deduction of &#128;1&nbsp;million (2014 and 2013: &#128;1 million) could give rise to deferred tax assets. The amount of notional interest deduction that has been accumulated in the past can be carried forward for maximum seven years, the notional
	interest deduction of 2012 and following years will not be carried forward according to a change in the Belgian tax legislation. There is no limit in time for the investment deduction.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The consolidated unused tax losses carried forward at December&nbsp;31, 2015 amounted to &#128;434&nbsp;million (2014: &#128;315 million; 2013: &#128;329
	million), &#128;19.3&nbsp;million were related to unrecognized tax losses with expiry date between 2018 and 2030.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The available statutory tax losses
	carried forward that can be offset against future statutory taxable profits amounted to &#128;265&nbsp;million on December&nbsp;31, 2015. These statutory tax losses can be compensated with future statutory profits for an indefinite period except for
	an amount of &#128;17&nbsp;million in Switzerland, Croatia, the United States and The Netherlands with expiry date between 2018 and 2030. On December&nbsp;31, 2015, the available tax losses carried forward in Galapagos NV (Belgium) amounted to
	&#128;184 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For two subsidiaries operating on a cost plus basis a deferred tax asset was set up for an amount of &#128;1.7&nbsp;million in 2015
	(2014: &#128;0.3 million; 2013: &#128;0 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-41
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage214"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have a history of losses. Excluding the impact of possible upfront or milestone payments to be received from
	collaborations, we forecast to continue incurring taxable losses in the foreseeable future as we continue to invest in clinical and pre-clinical development programs and discovery platforms. Consequently, no deferred tax asset has been set up as at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, except for two subsidiaries operating on a cost plus basis for which a deferred tax asset was set up (of &#128;1.7&nbsp;million as explained above).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">

</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;

</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We lease certain of our installation and machinery under finance leases. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the
	average borrowing rate was 4.30% (2014: 6.27%; 2013: 6.17%). The interest rates were fixed at the date of the contracts. All leases are on a fixed repayment basis and no arrangements have been entered into for contingent rental payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of our lease obligations approximates their carrying value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-42
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage215"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The trade and other liabilities, amounting to &#128;58.5&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2014, decreased by
	&#128;56.1&nbsp;million compared to the &#128;114.7&nbsp;million reported as of December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The trade and other payables amounting to &#128;29.3&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 remain stable compared to the &#128;29.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2013. The accrued charges show a decrease of
	&#128;3.3&nbsp;million compared to the ending balance on December&nbsp;31, 2013 which can be fully explained by the sale of the service division.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Deferred income amounts to &#128;27.0&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014, which decreased by &#128;52.0&nbsp;million compared to December&nbsp;31, 2013. This decrease can mainly be explained by revenues from
	non-refundable upfront payments recognized in the income statement for &#128;45.8 million. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, &#128;15.0&nbsp;million revenue was deferred for the filgotinib program for rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn&#146;s
	disease with AbbVie, and &#128;11.4&nbsp;million was deferred for the CF program with AbbVie. The remainder, being &#128;0.6&nbsp;million, was mainly composed of discounting effects on non-current R&amp;D incentives receivables and deferred revenues
	from grants.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The trade and other liabilities, amounting to &#128;72.1&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, increased by
	&#128;13.5&nbsp;million compared to the &#128;58.5&nbsp;million reported as of December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The trade and other payables amounting to &#128;29.1&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 remained stable compared to the &#128;29.3&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2014. Nevertheless, trade payables decreased
	by &#128;2.7&nbsp;million compared to the same period last year which fully compensated the increase in other payables by &#128;2.5&nbsp;million as a result of higher bonus provisions.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Deferred income amounted to &#128;39.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and increased by &#128;12.8&nbsp;million compared to December&nbsp;31, 2014. On the one hand there was an increase of &#128;39&nbsp;million
	due to the booking of the financial asset upon signing of the share subscription agreement with Gilead (see note 7). On the other hand there was a substantial decrease of &#128;26.4&nbsp;million, which can mainly be explained by revenues from
	non-refundable upfront payments recognized in the income statement. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, &#128;15.0&nbsp;million revenue was deferred for the filgotinib program for rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn&#146;s disease with AbbVie, and
	&#128;11.4&nbsp;million was deferred for the CF program with AbbVie.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The outstanding deferred income balance at December&nbsp;31, 2015 included &#128;39.0&nbsp;million deferred income related to the Gilead share subscription agreement and &#128;0.8&nbsp;million of discounting effects on
	non-current R&amp;D incentives receivables and deferred revenues from grants.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-43
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The decrease in provisions in 2014 is mainly due to the sale of the service division (&#128;0.6 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The decrease in provisions in 2015 is mainly due to the use of the provision for decontamination of the building in France (&#128;0.1 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	26. Operating lease obligations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We entered into lease
	agreements for office and laboratories which qualify as operating leases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Minimum lease payments under operating leases recognized in the income
	statement for the year
</I>

	&nbsp;

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	27. Off-balance sheet arrangements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<U>
	C
<SMALL>
	ONTRACTUAL
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	OBLIGATIONS
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	AND
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	COMMITMENTS
</SMALL>
</U>
<SMALL>
</SMALL>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We entered into lease agreements for office and laboratories which qualify as operating leases. We also have certain purchase commitments with CRO
	subcontractors principally.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had outstanding obligations for future minimum rent payments and purchase commitments, which
	become due as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	28. Contingent assets and liabilities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;13, 2014, we announced the signing of a definitive agreement to sell the service division operations to Charles River Laboratories International,
	Inc. (the &#147;Buyer&#148;) for a total consideration of up to &#128;134 million. Charles River agreed to pay us an immediate cash consideration of &#128;129 million. The potential earn-out of &#128;5&nbsp;million due upon achievement of a revenue
	target 12 months after transaction closing has not been obtained. Approximately 5% of the total consideration, including price adjustments, is being held on an escrow account. To date, four claims have been introduced by the Buyer, of which three
	claims have been settled for a total amount of &#128;1.0 million. One claim is still being investigated. An amount of &#128;0.3&nbsp;million has been accrued in March 2015 based on a preliminary estimate of the exposure. The release of the escrow
	account will be possible after final agreement between the parties on the amounts at stake.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following the divestment, we remain guarantor for a limited
	transitional period in respect of the lease obligations for certain U.K. premises amounting to &pound;4&nbsp;million future rent payments. The Buyer will fully indemnify us against all liabilities arising in connection with the lease obligation. We
	evaluated the risk to be remote. Finally, following common practice, we have given customary representations and warranties which are capped and limited in time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the course of 2008, a former director of one of the subsidiaries sued for wrongful termination and seeks damages of &#128;1.1 million. We believe that the
	amount of damages claimed is unrealistically high. In 2014, the court requested an external advisor to evaluate the exact amount of damages. Considering the defense elements provided and the recent judgment in the court in our favor, our Board and
	management evaluated the risk to be remote to possible, but not likely. Accordingly, it was decided not to record any provision in 2015 as the exposure is considered to be limited.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	29. Retirement benefit plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<U>
	D
<SMALL>
	EFINED
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	CONTRIBUTION
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	PLANS
</SMALL>
</U>
<SMALL>
</SMALL>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We operate defined contribution systems for all of our qualifying employees. The assets of the schemes are held separately from ours in designated pension
	plans. For defined contribution systems, we pay contributions to publicly or privately administered pension or insurance funds. Once the contribution is paid, we do not have any remaining obligation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our personnel in Belgium participates in a defined contribution plan (extra-legal pension). The Belgian defined contribution pension plans are by law subject
	to minimum guaranteed rates of return, 3.25% on employer contributions and 3.75% on employee contributions up to December&nbsp;31, 2015. These rates, which apply as an average over the entire career, could be modified by Royal Decree. Therefore,
	those plans were basically accounted for as defined contribution plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-45
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage218"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The contributions for those plans that were due by the employer for 2015, 2014 and 2013 amounted to respectively
	&#128;476.3&nbsp;thousand, &#128;465.6&nbsp;thousand and &#128;367.9&nbsp;million, of which &#128;35.9&nbsp;thousand was paid after December&nbsp;31, 2015 (2014: &#128;32.9 thousand; 2013: &#128;33.9 thousand). No contributions were made by the
	employees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The plan assets as at December&nbsp;31, 2015 consisted of &#128;1,063.7&nbsp;thousand individual insurance reserves, which benefit from a
	weighted average guaranteed interest rate of 3.0%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a consequence of the law of December&nbsp;18, 2015, minimum returns are guaranteed by the employer
	as follows: (a)&nbsp;for the contributions paid as from January&nbsp;1, 2016, a new variable minimum return based on OLO rates, with a minimum of 1.75% and a maximum of 3.75%. In review of the low rates of the OLO in the last years, the return has
	been initially set to 1.75%; (b)&nbsp;for the contributions paid until end of December 2015, the previously applied legal returns as mentioned above, continue to apply until the leaving of the employees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In view of the minimum returns guarantees, the Belgian defined contribution plans classify as defined benefit plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015 no net liability was recognized (2014 and 2013: nil) in the balance sheet as the minimum rates of return to be guaranteed by the
	employer are closely matched by the rates of return guaranteed by the insurer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Similar pension schemes apply to the entities in other countries, except
	in France. The amounts due by our continuing operations to these pension plans in 2015 were &#128;1.5&nbsp;million in total (2014: &#128;1.5 million; 2013: &#128;1.3 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<U>
	D
<SMALL>
	EFINED
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	BENEFIT
</SMALL>
<SMALL>
	PLANS
</SMALL>
</U>
<SMALL>
</SMALL>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We use two defined benefit plans for the employees of our French entity. The defined benefit plans are not supported by funds.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Chemical and Pharmaceutical Industry&#146;s collective bargaining agreements require that the French entity pays a retirement allowance depending on the
	seniority of the employees at the moment they retire. The benefit obligations for these retirement allowances amounted to &#128;1,520.9&nbsp;thousand for 2015 (2014: &#128;1,622.3 thousand; 2013: &#128;1,207.2 thousand). This decrease compared to
	2014 is mainly due to changed actuarial assumptions (increase of discount rate from 1.75% to 2%).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Additionally, there are also seniority premiums paid in
	France. The provisions for these premiums amounted to &#128;1,172.0&nbsp;thousand in 2015 (2014: &#128;1,242.9 thousand; 2013: &#128;981.8 thousand).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total obligation included in the balance sheet related to the defined benefit plans amounts to &#128;2,692.9&nbsp;thousand for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 (2014: &#128;2,865.2 thousand; 2013: &#128;2,189.0 thousand).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Actuarial gains and losses are recognized immediately on the balance
	sheet, with a charge or credit to other comprehensive income (OCI), in accordance with IAS 19R. They are not recycled subsequently. Actuarial gains of &#128;201.5&nbsp;thousand have been booked through other comprehensive income (OCI) at the end of
	2015 (2014: &#128;266.6&nbsp;thousand of actuarial losses; 2013: &#128;46.6&nbsp;thousand of actuarial gains).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-46
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	30. Warrant plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Presented below is a summary of warrant plans activities for the reported periods. Various warrant plans were approved for the benefit of our employees, and
	for Directors and independent consultants of Galapagos NV. For warrant plans issued prior to 2011, the warrants offered to the employees and independent consultants vest according to the following schedule: 10% of the warrants vest on the date of
	the grant; an additional 10% vest at the first anniversary of the grant; an additional 20% vest at the second anniversary of the grant; an additional 20% vest at the third anniversary of the grant; and an additional 40% vest at the end of the third
	calendar year following the grant. The warrants granted under warrant plans created from 2011 up to (and including) Warrant Plan 2015 vest at the end of the third calendar year following the year of the grant, with no intermediate vesting. The
	warrants granted under Warrant Plan 2015 (B)&nbsp;and Warrant Plan 2015 RMV vest on the third anniversary of the notary deed enacting the acceptance of the warrants. The warrants offered to Directors vest over a period of 36 months at a rate of
	1/36th&nbsp;per month. Warrants cannot be exercised before the end of the third calendar year following the year of the grant, except for warrants granted under Warrant Plan 2015 (B)&nbsp;and Warrant Plan 2015 RMV, which become exercisable on the
	third anniversary of the notary deed enacting the acceptance of the warrants. Pursuant to a resolution adopted at the Extraordinary Shareholders&#146; Meeting held on May&nbsp;23, 2011, a provision has been incorporated in the warrant plans, which
	provides that in the event of a change of control over Galapagos NV, all outstanding warrants vest immediately and will be immediately exercisable.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	After
	the reverse 4:1 share split approved by the Shareholders&#146; Meeting held on March&nbsp;29, 2005, four warrants under Warrant Plan 2002 Belgium entitle the warrant holder to subscribe for one ordinary share. For the warrant
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-49
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage222"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	plans created from 2005 onwards, one warrant entitles the warrant holder to subscribe for one ordinary share. In the summaries and tables below, the numbers of warrants issued under Warrant Plan
	2002 Belgium are divided by four to avoid confusion in entitlements and rights.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The summaries and tables below do not take into account the warrants
	granted under Warrant Plan 2015 (B)&nbsp;(i.e. 399,000 warrants) and Warrant Plan 2015 RMV (i.e. 97,500 warrants). The warrants under these plans were offered on December&nbsp;22, 2015 and as per December&nbsp;31, 2015 their issuance was still
	subject to acceptance by the beneficiaries. As per December&nbsp;31, 2015, they were not yet formally accepted nor issued
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The table below sets forth a
	summary of warrants outstanding and exercisable at December&nbsp;31, 2015,&nbsp;per warrant plan:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The exercise price of the warrants is determined pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Belgian Companies Code.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The estimated volatility is calculated on the basis of the historical volatility of the share price over the expected life of the warrants, validated by
	reference to the volatility of a representative biotech index.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The time to expiration of the warrant is calculated as the estimated duration until
	exercise, taking into account the specific features of the plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The warrants have been accounted for in accordance with International Financial
	Reporting Standard 2 on Share Based Payments. IFRS 2 takes effect for all warrants offered after November&nbsp;7, 2002.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-51
</P>

	Our warrants expense in 2015 amounted to &#128;5,036&nbsp;thousand (2014: &#128;2,952 thousand; 2013: &#128;2,742
	thousand).

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The outstanding warrants at the end of the accounting period have an average exercise price of &#128;16.22 (2014: &#128;12.06;
	2013: &#128;11.50) and a weighted average remaining expected life of 1,469 days (2014: 1,639 days; 2013: 1,628 days).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	31. Related parties
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Intercompany transactions between Galapagos NV and its subsidiaries, and amongst the subsidiaries, have been eliminated in the consolidation and are not
	disclosed in this note.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Trading transactions
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	2015, 2014 and 2013, Galapagos NV and its affiliates had no trading transactions with parties that are considered as related parties as defined in IAS24.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Potential conflicts of interest between the Company and its directors
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to the decision of the Annual Shareholders&#146; Meeting of April&nbsp;28, 2015, the total maximum amount of the annual remuneration for all Directors
	together (other than Dr.&nbsp;Parekh and the CEO) for the exercise of their mandate as a Director of Galapagos NV is fixed, on an aggregate basis, at &#128;200,000 (plus expenses). The same Annual Shareholders&#146; Meeting granted a power of
	attorney to the Board to determine the remuneration of the individual Board members within the limits of said aggregate amount. Pursuant to this power of attorney, the Board determined, after discussion within our nomination and remuneration
	committee, the allocation of the aggregate annual remuneration for Directors as follows: (a)&nbsp;annual remuneration for each non-executive Director (Dr.&nbsp;Cautreels, Dr.&nbsp;Van Barlingen, Mr.&nbsp;Rowe and Ms.&nbsp;Bosley): &#128;40,000; and
	(b)&nbsp;additional remuneration for the chairman of the Audit Committee (Dr. Cautreels): &#128;5,000. Dr.&nbsp;Mummery, being appointed as non-executive Director as from September&nbsp;30, 2015, received &#128;10,000 as remuneration for the
	performance of her mandate during the last quarter of 2015. Dr.&nbsp;Parekh, the Chairman of the Board, is compensated through a consultancy agreement only (see remuneration of key management).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There are no loans between Galapagos NV and the members of its Board of Directors or its Executive Committee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The remuneration of key management (including the CEO) is set out further below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015 (as in 2014), there were no arrangements or understandings with major shareholders pursuant to which a representative of such shareholder became a
	member of Galapagos NV&#146;s Board of Directors or its Executive Committee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-52
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage225"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D167585D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, a total of 116,740 warrants were issued to the Directors, of which 100,000 for the CEO; these warrants
	were issued by the Board of Directors within the framework of the authorized capital, in accordance with the resolution of the Shareholders&#146; Meeting of April&nbsp;28, 2015. In 2014, the total number of warrants issued to Directors was 119,260
	(of which 100,000 for the CEO); these warrants were issued by the Board of Directors within the framework of the authorized capital, in accordance with the resolution of the Shareholders&#146; Meeting of April&nbsp;29, 2014. The above does not take
	into consideration the 152,500 warrants offered to the Directors, of which 100,000 to the CEO, under Warrant Plan 2015 (B), as these warrants were offered on December&nbsp;22, 2015 subject to acceptance of the beneficiaries, and were not yet
	formally accepted and issued as per December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

	Dr.&nbsp;Andre Hoekema. The remuneration package of the members of the Executive Committee who were in function in the course of 2015 comprises:
